<div class="c6 " style="margin-bottom:7px">
<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
BANKING
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/04/13/banks-first-pandemic-earnings-reports?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Because Someone's Gotta Go First...
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="Bank safe with mask inside" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC81ODUvYmFua19zYWZlLmpwZyIsImJ1Y2tldCI6Im9zbG8tcHJvZHVjdGlvbiIsImVkaXRzIjp7InJlc2l6ZSI6eyJ3aWR0aCI6MTAwMCwiaGVpZ2h0IjpudWxsfX19">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Francis Scialabba</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The biggest U.S. banks are kicking earnings season into gear this week, but what's typically a routine financial checkup now feels like a corporate colonoscopy. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Bank stocks have dropped <a href="https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-04-13/banks-poised-to-open-earnings-season-with-surge-in-volatility?sref=1crrKBaO&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">about 35%</a> year-to-date, nearly wiping out last year's gains. Options traders are betting the pandemic-induced crisis will send shares swinging wildly, with implied volatility nearly triple what it was heading into January's earnings calls. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">KBW analysts <a href="https://www.marketwatch.com/story/bank-earnings-preview-as-industry-profits-get-cut-in-half-the-winners-will-emerge-next-year-2020-04-07?mod=home-page&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">lowered</a> earnings estimates by 58% for 2020 and 50% next year. But "whether a bank 'beats' or 'misses' first-quarter earnings estimates will be meaningless," MarketWatch reports, because results will be affected by banks beefing up reserves ahead of a wave of expected defaults on existing loans. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Other forces <a href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/bank-stocks-are-in-a-ditch-earnings-wont-change-that-11586689201?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">turning</a> Jamie Dimon’s hair from gray to white: </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>The Fed cutting interest rates near zero last quarter (reducing the profits banks can make off loans) </span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Hits to corporate advisory arms as companies freeze M&A</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Four straight weeks of declining home purchase applications</span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Two reasons why the sky isn’t totally falling: </strong>Trading arms probably got a boost when the stock market tanked in March. And businesses whose revenue suddenly dried up have been tapping credit lines like a cold brew keg. Banks have<a href="https://www.ft.com/content/9fffbcf4-b2f1-4017-9c1e-ed7ddd2add31?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333"> extended $223 billion</a> so far this year, nearly two-thirds of which took place from March 17–19. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Congress's $2.2 trillion relief package and new Fed programs to lend to small businesses might siphon off some of that business in the coming weeks. </span></li>
</ul>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">Looking ahead</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">JPMorgan’s Dimon, who’s up first this morning along with Wells Fargo, already conceded “earnings will be down meaningfully in 2020” in last week’s <a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/04/06/jamie-dimons-annual-shareholder-letter-focuses-covid19-impacts?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">letter to shareholders</a>. Bank of America, Citigroup, and Goldman Sachs report tomorrow, and Morgan Stanley will follow up on Thursday. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Investors will be listening closely for banks to give details on any relief they're offering to affected customers and workers, as well as when execs think things will return to "normal," whatever that means anymore.</p>

<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
INTERNATIONAL
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/04/13/report-israel-releases-4part-reopening-plan?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
How Israel Plans to Restart Its Economy
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Listen, we're like you—we'll read <em>anything</em> that provides a blueprint for getting life back to 10% of normal. One interesting guide comes from Israel, where the country's National Security Council has reportedly <a href="https://www.haaretz.com/israel-news/.premium-hi-tech-and-preschools-then-malls-and-sports-israel-s-coronavirus-exit-strategy-1.8762359?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">finalized a plan</a> to slowly lift stay-at-home restrictions.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The plan consists of four phases and focuses on opening more lucrative sectors first, Haaretz reports:</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Phase 1: </strong>Tech and finance, plus slices of trade-oriented industries. These sectors employ more than 10% of the population. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Phase 2: </strong>Commerce and retail stores. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Phase 3: </strong>Restaurants and hotels. The NSC expects most of the education system will be back at this point, too.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Phase 4: </strong>Recreational sectors like sports, air travel, and entertainment.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">If that seems like a straightforward process, consider these caveats:</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Each phase will have a two-week buffer to review whether the next can proceed.</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>All of the public health guidelines we've been subject to (social distancing, face masks, etc.) will be required for reopening industries.</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>None of these phases applies to people over 60 and other at-risk populations.</span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Bottom line: </strong>Coronavirus restrictions will almost definitely extend into the summer.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">+ While we're here: </strong>NY, NJ, and a few other northeastern states have <a href="https://www.axios.com/cuomo-new-york-coronavirus-reopening-ee97646b-d69d-4221-9f30-c43b6f6763a8.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">formed a task force</a> to coordinate reopening their economies. So have some <a href="https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/2020/04/13/newsom-west-coast-states-readying-reopen-economies-together/2984154001/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">West Coast states</a>.</p>

<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
E-COMMERCE
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/04/13/amazon-announces-new-positions-hands-lifeline-thirdparty-sellers?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Amazon Keeps Going...and Going...
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="Amazon boxes" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC80MTkvYW1hem9uX2JveC5wbmciLCJidWNrZXQiOiJvc2xvLXByb2R1Y3Rpb24iLCJlZGl0cyI6eyJyZXNpemUiOnsid2lkdGgiOjEwMDAsImhlaWdodCI6bnVsbH19fQ==">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Francis Scialabba</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">You may be practicing TikTok dances for five hours a day, but things have never been busier in Bezosland. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">After prioritizing shipments of medical supplies and other high-demand products for the last month, Amazon has given third-party sellers the <a href="https://www.cnbc.com/2020/04/13/amazon-allows-sellers-to-start-shipping-non-essential-items-again.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">green light</a> to once again ship limited quantities of "non-essential" items to warehouses, signaling a renewed focus on getting customers the indoor putting green they’ve been waiting on for weeks. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">As for your eclairs, </strong>you might need to keep waiting. Despite <a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/04/09/walmarts-grocery-app-surges-past-amazon?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">heavy competition</a> from Walmart, demand for Amazon's expanded grocery pick up and delivery service is sky-high...</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>So high, that starting yesterday, customers who signed up for the service were automatically </span><span><a href="https://techcrunch.com/2020/04/13/amazon-puts-new-online-grocery-shoppers-on-a-waitlist/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">added to a waitlist</a></span><span>.</span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Keep in mind, the worker packing your box will most likely be a noobie. After filling the 100,000 new positions it opened in March, Amazon said yesterday it's hiring 75,000 <em>more</em> warehouse and distribution workers this month. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Along with increasing hourly wages and offering two weeks of paid sick leave, Amazon has focused on <a href="https://blog.aboutamazon.com/company-news/update-from-amazons-operations-network?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">making safety upgrades</a> to protect new employees from the coronavirus following criticism.</p>

<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Like many of you, our days have moved mostly indoors, and we are out of excuses <em>not </em>to give bullet journaling a try. <th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">

<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
FOOD
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/04/13/plant-closures-threaten-us-meat-supplies?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
BLT, but Hold the B
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Over the weekend, one of the U.S.’ largest pork processing plants <a href="https://www.businessinsider.com/sick-workers-closures-hit-meat-suppliers-sparking-shortage-fears-2020-4?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">halted operations</a> after hundreds of employees contracted COVID-19, the latest closure by a major meat producer. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>The plant’s operator, Smithfield Foods, accounts for nearly 18 million daily servings of meat. Its president warned that the U.S.’ meat supply is “perilously close to the edge.” </span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Food shortage fears have bounced around for weeks as shoppers stare down empty shelves. But short supplies are more a byproduct of demand spikes from <a href="https://www.vice.com/en_us/article/g5x7w3/why-grocery-store-shelves-look-bare-even-though-theres-no-food-shortage?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">frenzied customers</a> and supply chain disruptions, Vice reports. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Many farmers are actually trying to send <em>more</em> food to grocery stores as commercial customers like hotels, schools, and restaurants cancel orders. But reworking your supply chain is a logistical nightmare even in a good economy.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Some producers have nowhere to send supplies. Farmers have left veggies rotting in fields and dumped millions of gallons of milk. The seafood industry is practically <a href="https://www.grocerydive.com/news/seafood-industry-looks-to-retail-for-a-lifeline-as-sales-plummet/575813/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">throwing</a> fresh lobster at customers as fishery sales capsize as much as 95%. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Looking ahead…</strong>the pandemic could <a href="https://seattle.eater.com/2020/4/2/21206010/seattle-butcher-shops-beast-and-cleaver-farms-coronavirus-economic-impact?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">accelerate direct-to-consumer sales</a> of groceries, fresh meat, and other supplies.  </p>

<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
CONSUMER GOODS
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/04/13/brands-enjoy-renaissance-coronavirus-quarantines?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Forgotten Brands Enjoy a Renaissance With a Side of Mac
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<!--[if mso]>
<img alt="Creation of Adam" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" height=305 src="https://oslo-production.s3.amazonaws.com/uploads/medium/asset/584/handshake.gif">
<![endif]-->
<!--[if !mso]>--><!-- -->
<img class="story-header-image" alt="Creation of Adam" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" src="https://oslo-production.s3.amazonaws.com/uploads/medium/asset/584/handshake.gif">
<!--<![endif]-->
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Giphy</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">14th–17th century Renaissance: </strong>A period of flowering artistic expression giving rise to timeless works of art, calculus, and the printing press.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">2020 Renaissance: </strong>A period of quarantine giving rise to timeless days, junk food, and jigsaw puzzles. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">As COVID-19 jolted people from their daily routines, industries and pastimes once tossed aside are making a surprising comeback.</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>
</span><span><strong style="color:#000">Processed food: </strong></span><span>A struggling Kraft Heinz enjoyed a </span><span><a href="https://qz.com/1834943/coronavirus-gives-kraft-heinz-its-first-sales-bump-in-years/?utm_source=email&utm_medium=daily-brief&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">3% increase in sales</a></span><span> in the first quarter of 2020 as a nation that shunned processed food in recent years returned to the comfort of a steaming bowl of boxed mac and cheese.</span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>
</span><span><strong style="color:#000">Jigsaw puzzles: </strong></span><span>136-year-old puzzle maker Ravensburger sold an average of seven puzzles per minute in North America. Since the beginning of April, the company’s been selling puzzles at a rate of </span><span><a href="https://www.cnbc.com/2020/04/03/coronavirus-sends-demand-for-jigsaw-puzzles-surging.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">nearly 20 per minute</a></span><span>—a nearly 286% increase.</span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>
</span><span><strong style="color:#000">Houseparty: </strong></span><span>While Zoom has cornered boardroom communication, Houseparty has reemerged as a go-to place for spontaneous video hangouts among friends. The app, first released in 2016, saw </span><span><a href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/cooped-up-with-the-kids-a-new-generation-crashes-the-houseparty-11586793114?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">17 million downloads</a></span><span> in March. </span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Looking ahead...</strong>the Enlightenment.</p>

PODCAST
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">

<font color="#000000">
How COVID-19 Impacts Your Personal Finance
</font></a>

<img alt="Ramit Sethi / Business Casual" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC81ODIvcmFtaXRfc2V0aGlfYnVzaW5lc3NfY2FzdWFsLmpwZyIsImJ1Y2tldCI6Im9zbG8tcHJvZHVjdGlvbiIsImVkaXRzIjp7InJlc2l6ZSI6eyJ3aWR0aCI6MTAwMCwiaGVpZ2h0IjpudWxsfX19">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Francis Scialabba</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Life may be tough right now...but you might be about to get a check in the mail from the government.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">So what should you do with that money?</strong> Once your necessities are covered, is it best to splurge or save? And what kind of impact—if any—will these payouts have on the U.S. economy?</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">This week on Morning Brew’s </strong><strong style="color:#000"><em>Business Casual</em></strong><strong style="color:#000"> podcast, </strong>we’re diving into personal finance in the COVID-19 age with money expert and <em>I Will Teach You to Be Rich</em> author Ramit Sethi. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Listen here:</strong> <a href="https://link.chtbl.com/ramitsethi_apple?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Apple</a> / <a href="https://link.chtbl.com/ramitsethi_Spotify?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Spotify</a> / <a href="https://link.chtbl.com/ramitsethi_all?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">everywhere else</a></p>

Chaser: That's without any more spending to alleviate the coronavirus crisis.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003c/th\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003c!--[if !mso ]\u003e\u003c! -- --\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c!-- \u003c![endif]--\u003e\n\u003c!-- END MARKETS --\u003e\n\u003c!-- ARTICLE ---\u003e\n\u003c!--[if !mso ]\u003e\u003c! -- --\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"c6 \" style=\"margin-bottom:7px\"\u003e\n\u003c!-- \u003c![endif]--\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003cth class=\"card\" style=\"text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px\"\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding: 15px;\"\u003e\n\u003ch3 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0\"\u003e\nBANKING\n\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003ch1 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px\"\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/04/13/banks-first-pandemic-earnings-reports?email={{profile.email}}\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;\"\u003e\n\u003cfont color=\"#000000\"\u003e\nBecause Someone's Gotta Go First...\n\u003c/font\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003c/h1\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003cimg alt=\"Bank safe with mask inside\" style=\"display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;\" width=\"670\" class=\"story-header-image\" src=\"https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC81ODUvYmFua19zYWZlLmpwZyIsImJ1Y2tldCI6Im9zbG8tcHJvZHVjdGlvbiIsImVkaXRzIjp7InJlc2l6ZSI6eyJ3aWR0aCI6MTAwMCwiaGVpZ2h0IjpudWxsfX19\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;\"\u003e\n\u003csmall\u003e\u003cem\u003eFrancis Scialabba\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThe biggest U.S. banks are kicking earnings season into gear this week, but what's typically a routine financial checkup now feels like a corporate colonoscopy. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eBank stocks have dropped \u003ca href=\"https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-04-13/banks-poised-to-open-earnings-season-with-surge-in-volatility?sref=1crrKBaO\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eabout 35%\u003c/a\u003e year-to-date, nearly wiping out last year's gains. Options traders are betting the pandemic-induced crisis will send shares swinging wildly, with implied volatility nearly triple what it was heading into January's earnings calls. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eKBW analysts \u003ca href=\"https://www.marketwatch.com/story/bank-earnings-preview-as-industry-profits-get-cut-in-half-the-winners-will-emerge-next-year-2020-04-07?mod=home-page\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003elowered\u003c/a\u003e earnings estimates by 58% for 2020 and 50% next year. But \"whether a bank 'beats' or 'misses' first-quarter earnings estimates will be meaningless,\" MarketWatch reports, because results will be affected by banks beefing up reserves ahead of a wave of expected defaults on existing loans. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eOther forces \u003ca href=\"https://www.wsj.com/articles/bank-stocks-are-in-a-ditch-earnings-wont-change-that-11586689201?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eturning\u003c/a\u003e Jamie Dimon’s hair from gray to white: \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eThe Fed cutting interest rates near zero last quarter (reducing the profits banks can make off loans) \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eHits to corporate advisory arms as companies freeze M\u0026A\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eFour straight weeks of declining home purchase applications\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eTwo reasons why the sky isn’t totally falling: \u003c/strong\u003eTrading arms probably got a boost when the stock market tanked in March. And businesses whose revenue suddenly dried up have been tapping credit lines like a cold brew keg. Banks have\u003ca href=\"https://www.ft.com/content/9fffbcf4-b2f1-4017-9c1e-ed7ddd2add31?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003e extended $223 billion\u003c/a\u003e so far this year, nearly two-thirds of which took place from March 17–19. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eCongress's $2.2 trillion relief package and new Fed programs to lend to small businesses might siphon off some of that business in the coming weeks. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eLooking ahead\u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eJPMorgan’s Dimon, who’s up first this morning along with Wells Fargo, already conceded “earnings will be down meaningfully in 2020” in last week’s \u003ca href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/04/06/jamie-dimons-annual-shareholder-letter-focuses-covid19-impacts?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eletter to shareholders\u003c/a\u003e. Bank of America, Citigroup, and Goldman Sachs report tomorrow, and Morgan Stanley will follow up on Thursday. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eInvestors will be listening closely for banks to give details on any relief they're offering to affected customers and workers, as well as when execs think things will return to \"normal,\" whatever that means anymore.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0\"\u003e\nINTERNATIONAL\n\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003ch1 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, style=\"color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;\"\u003e\n\u003cfont color=\"#000000\"\u003e\nHow Israel Plans to Restart Its Economy\n\u003c/font\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003c/h1\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eListen, we're like you—we'll read \u003cem\u003eanything\u003c/em\u003e that provides a blueprint for getting life back to 10% of normal. One interesting guide comes from Israel, where the country's National Security Council has reportedly \u003ca href=\"https://www.haaretz.com/israel-news/.premium-hi-tech-and-preschools-then-malls-and-sports-israel-s-coronavirus-exit-strategy-1.8762359?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003efinalized a plan\u003c/a\u003e to slowly lift stay-at-home restrictions.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThe plan consists of four phases and focuses on opening more lucrative sectors first, Haaretz reports:\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003ePhase 1: \u003c/strong\u003eTech and finance, plus slices of trade-oriented industries. These sectors employ more than 10% of the population. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003ePhase 2: \u003c/strong\u003eCommerce and retail stores. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003ePhase 3: \u003c/strong\u003eRestaurants and hotels. The NSC expects most of the education system will be back at this point, too.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003ePhase 4: \u003c/strong\u003eRecreational sectors like sports, air travel, and entertainment.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eIf that seems like a straightforward process, consider these caveats:\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eEach phase will have a two-week buffer to review whether the next can proceed.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eAll of the public health guidelines we've been subject to (social distancing, face masks, etc.) will be required for reopening industries.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eNone of these phases applies to people over 60 and other at-risk populations.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBottom line: \u003c/strong\u003eCoronavirus restrictions will almost definitely extend into the summer.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003e+ While we're here: \u003c/strong\u003eNY, NJ, and a few other northeastern states have \u003ca href=\"https://www.axios.com/cuomo-new-york-coronavirus-reopening-ee97646b-d69d-4221-9f30-c43b6f6763a8.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eformed a task force\u003c/a\u003e to coordinate reopening their economies. So have some \u003ca href=\"https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/2020/04/13/newsom-west-coast-states-readying-reopen-economies-together/2984154001/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eWest Coast states\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS producer. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eThe plant’s operator, Smithfield Foods, accounts for nearly 18 million daily servings of meat. Its president warned that the U.S.’ meat supply is “perilously close to the edge.” \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eFood shortage fears have bounced around for weeks as shoppers stare down empty shelves. But short supplies are more a byproduct of demand spikes from \u003ca href=\"https://www.vice.com/en_us/article/g5x7w3/why-grocery-store-shelves-look-bare-even-though-theres-no-food-shortage?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003efrenzied customers\u003c/a\u003e and supply chain disruptions, Vice reports. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eMany farmers are actually trying to send \u003cem\u003emore\u003c/em\u003e food to grocery stores as commercial customers like hotels, schools, and restaurants cancel orders. But reworking your supply chain is a logistical nightmare even in a good economy.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eSome producers have nowhere to send supplies. Farmers have left veggies rotting in fields and dumped millions of gallons of milk. The seafood industry is practically \u003ca href=\"https://www.grocerydive.com/news/seafood-industry-looks-to-retail-for-a-lifeline-as-sales-plummet/575813/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\"
